Groundhog Day Alert!

Folks, we can’t make this up. Keep your eye on the weather tomorrow from late afternoon into the early evening – right around 5pm. There is another severe thunderstorm system making its way out of the west that has the potential for damaging winds, isolated tornadoes, and large hail. The storm system also has the potential for some heavy rainfall. There have been two similar type storm systems pass through Colquitt County in the last few days and weeks. This will be the third. Most of the damage from the previous storms was from high winds. Last Monday, an EF-2 tornado did touch down in neighboring Worth County so please pay attention to your local weather stations. Your county employees will be on stand-by should the need arise.

Like you, we are ready for a break in the weather and a break from Corona. Who else is looking forward to Hurricane Season?

Hello, again. I hope that everyone is managing to get by during these difficult times. It seems as though the social distancing guidelines are working to slow the progression of COVID-19. Let’s all continue to do our part in helping to end this pandemic. No matter how much we hope the government can come up with a quick fix, the coronavirus can only be stopped by each and every one of us exercising our individual responsibility to make ourselves and everyone around us safer.

I would like to take this opportunity to remind everyone about the importance of the Census. Please take advantage of any free time you may have to go online or complete the form that has been mailed to you. We want to make sure everyone is counted because it plays a major factor in the amount of state and federal funding that the county is eligible for, thus keeping our local property taxes to a minimum.

Thank you for your time and, as always, feel free to contact me, your district commissioner, or any county staff if you have any questions or concerns.

Yours Truly,

Denver F. Braswell

Hello, again. I hope that everyone is managing to get by during these difficult times. It seems as though the social distancing guidelines are working to slow the progression of COVID-19. Let’s all continue to do our part in helping to end this pandemic. No matter how much we hope the government can come up with a quick fix, the coronavirus can only be stopped by each and every one of us exercising our individual responsibility to make ourselves and everyone around us safer.

I would like to take this opportunity to remind everyone about the importance of the Census. Please take advantage of any free time you may have to go online or complete the form that has been mailed to you. We want to make sure everyone is counted because it plays a major factor in the amount of state and federal funding that the county is eligible for, thus keeping our local property taxes to a minimum.

Thank you for your time and, as always, feel free to contact me, your district commissioner, or any county staff if you have any questions or concerns.

Yours Truly,

Denver F. Braswell

post_text: HURRICANE DORIAN UPDATE: This morning, public safety representatives from multiple agencies within Colquitt County met to begin preliminary planning for Hurricane Dorian. At this point, we do not have a clear understanding of the exact path the storm will follow. However, we do expect the path and trajectory to become more apparent over the next 24-48 hours. On Sunday, September 1st at 3:30, we will hold a follow-up meeting in the County Annex. At the conclusion of that meeting, we hope to be able to provide our citizens with updates regarding school closures, evacuation guidance (if there is any), law enforcement restrictions, and any relevant information regarding available storm shelters within the county. There is a possibility that the storm path and direction may still not be clear at the time of our Sunday meeting. If that is the case, we will provide updated information to you as soon as possible. Please continue to monitor weather forecasts and pray that this storm weakens and stays away from Southwest Georgia.

Today, we mourn the loss of one of our own.

A delight to her fellow employees, Wendy was always singing and had a great sense of humor. As a 911 Telecommunications Operator, Wendy loved all her units and their safety was extremely important to her. If a co-worker or friend was ever in need, Wendy was always there to check on them or to lift their spirits.

Her dedication to her job and the county was evident – Wendy had not missed a single day of work since December 2017.
Wendy will be greatly missed by all who were privileged enough to know her.

Our thoughts and prayers go out to Wendy’s family during this difficult time.

Orientation for our 2020 Census Complete Count Committee was held recently at the Courthouse Annex. Guests from the Census Bureau were also in attendance to give an overview of the Census.

Complete Count Committees (CCCs) are established to motivate and increase census response. CCCs also play an integral role in ensuring a thorough and accurate count of the community in the 2020 Census.

Accurate census data is vital because it not only assists in planning and implementing programs and services but it can also determine federal funding, transportation needs, and the redistricting of state legislative districts.

Special thanks to our local Archway Professional Sarah Adams for serving as our resource guide during this process.

post_text: Hurricane Florence update: We are continuing to monitor the path of Hurricane Florence as it moves towards the Carolinas. Some of the models are predicting that the storm may move in a southwesterly direction and into Georgia after impacting the east coast. We will have a better idea of the storm’s track by tomorrow (Thursday) afternoon. If it does continue on a southwestern trajectory before or after making landfall, we can expect to feel some light to moderate impacts of the storm here in Colquitt County potentially as early as late Friday evening / early Saturday morning. At this point, that would include winds from 15 - 30 mph with some moderate rainfall. As we continue to watch this storm develop, we will provide additional information as we receive it.
